answers.answer: Hello.Do you have hypertension detected? High blood pressure is associated with multiple sites of small infarcts in the white matter, at the junction of white matter and the gray matter. This condition needs to be followed up regularly. A repeat MRI should be done after about six months. The balance issues are worrisome. They seem a bit more extensive than what the MRI would suggest. I was expecting a cerebellar lesion.Regards

Dr Deshmukh,Thank you for your response.My blood pressure has always been very good.  I think the highest it has ever been was 128/90 give or take. I do not have diabetes, but I do suffer from headaches.  I am 40 years old and work out about 3-5 days a week, it hasn't helped me lose weight but I still do it.  I am 5'3", 165 pounds.  So I am about 40-45 pounds overweight.  I am also a smoker.When I had the nerve test done (my sister was with me during the tests), the lady doing the test at one point said "I am going to have to go get something to warm up your arms to see if what I am seeing is accurate."  She said it was showing that my nerves were slow.  When she warmed up my arms she said there was not much improvement.  So I was a little surprised when the doctor said everything was fine.The neurologist said that my exam was normal, the nerve test/EMG (arms only) and MRI was normal.  On my last visit with him he asked me "do you need to see me anymore".  I told him I would come back if I needed to.  It just seems that maybe there should have been a follow up MRI or maybe some more test.  A few friends have suggested getting a 2nd opinion but I don't want to make a big deal out of nothing.Thanks again for your time, it is greatly appreciated.

question: Could I get some advice/clarification in regards to MRI results.I have been having some neurological issues, which was the reason for the MRI.  I have loss of balance, tripping, dropping things, falling to the side, back when walking and standing.  I can not stand without holding onto something.  I sometimes have speech problems, mumbling, slurring.  I also have widespread pain in arms, legs, knees, elbows etc.  I have had twitiching of the fingers on my left hand and also on my toe of my right foot.  I will also get muscle twitching in my calf, thighs, arms, ribs.  If I try to hold paper or something in my hand, my hand gets weak.  I am also having a very hard time with remembering things.  I have to really focus on things (in a distance) before they come clear.  My right leg gets numb and feels like I have less control of it than my left leg.This is the results of the MRI "FLAIR imaging sequence demonstrates two focal abnormal bright intensity foci in the subcortical white matter of the left frontal lobe and about four to five subcortical bright intensity foci in the left parietal white matter.  A single lesion is seen in the right parietal subcortical white matter.  These are most likely due to chronic small vessel disease and ischemic changes."With the results of the MRI should there be a follow up MRI done at a later date?  I did have a Nerve Conduction Test which showed minor abnormalties (but nothing to worry about according to the neurologist).  The EMG was normal and a eye exam was normal.  The neurologist does not feel there is a need to do a follow up MRI at a later date, and I am not sure if I am comfortable with that at this point.Any insight you can give me would be greatly appreciate.
title: MRI Clarification
